Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: One day last fall, Bryant Woods’ rotted-out flooring opened up beneath his 11-year-old daughter. Major leaks in the rental home had allowed mold to thrive and rot to set in. In the winters, he was forced to use space heaters or his electric oven to stay warm since the heat didn’t work.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating. About nine months ago, the two men agreed he could withhold rent until repairs were made, he said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating. About nine months ago, the two men agreed he could withhold rent until repairs were made, he said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: For years, Woods’ relationship with his longtime landlord has been deteriorating.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Then, recently, his landlord caught him by surprise and filed for eviction. He couldn’t prove his missed rent payments were part of a verbal agreement, so the judge granted the property owner’s request and told Woods his family had 10 days to move.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Then, recently, his landlord caught him by surprise and filed for eviction.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He left the courthouse without much hope.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: He left the courthouse without much hope.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: To reduce such evictions, one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: To reduce such evictions, one of the court’s judges, Deborah Henderson; Shelby County Commissioner Erika Sugarmon; and Cindy Ettingoff, then-CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services, last summer secured $240,000 in the county budget to pilot a pre-litigation mediation program for landlord-tenant disputes.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The initial goal was for MALS to use the money to hire a few employees — including a former code inspector since property conditions almost always drive the disputes. The nonprofit would then find tenants and landlords who seemed headed toward eviction and prevent at least 300 evictions — all in a year. The founders hoped this type of impact would prove the need for a specialized housing court in Shelby County, where judges could take a property’s condition into account when deciding eviction cases — as opposed to simply whether a tenant was behind on rent.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: The initial goal was for MALS to use the money to hire a few employees — including a former code inspector since property conditions almost always drive the disputes.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: But receiving the money from the county turned into an adventure. The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: But receiving the money from the county turned into an adventure. The cash didn’t make it to MALS until February 2024, due to problems with how the County Commission resolution was originally drafted, Henderson said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Recently, MALS worked with a woman who was living in a house that “should not be lived in by anyone” and was starting to fall behind on rent, Henderson said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Recently, MALS worked with a woman who was living in a house that “should not be lived in by anyone” and was starting to fall behind on rent, Henderson said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Though the program has only helped a couple of tenants so far — not 300 — Henderson believes it’s already proving its value.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Though the program has only helped a couple of tenants so far — not 300 — Henderson believes it’s already proving its value.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There are no income limits or income requirements,” Henderson told a WLOK-AM audience earlier this summer. “If you’re a tenant who is having trouble with your landlord, you need to give us a call. … If you’re a landlord and you have a troublesome tenant … give us a call.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: “There are no income limits or income requirements,” Henderson told a WLOK-AM audience earlier this summer.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: For the program to succeed, Grida said raising greater awareness will be key, as most Memphians it could help don’t yet know it exists.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: For the program to succeed, Grida said raising greater awareness will be key, as most Memphians it could help don’t yet know it exists.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Woods’ case, for instance, sounded like a perfect fit for mediation, Henderson said, if only they’d found him before the eviction was filed.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Woods’ case, for instance, sounded like a perfect fit for mediation, Henderson said, if only they’d found him before the eviction was filed.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “We could have drafted a document that ensured the landlord (followed the verbal agreement),” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: “We could have drafted a document that ensured the landlord (followed the verbal agreement),” she said.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Though the mediation program just launched, it’s going to have to quickly prove its impact. Its leaders are scheduled to present to the County Commission at the end of 2024, in hopes they can receive additional county funding after this first $240,000 runs out in February 2025.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Though the mediation program just launched, it’s going to have to quickly prove its impact. Its leaders are scheduled to present to the County Commission at the end of 2024, in hopes they can receive additional county funding after this first $240,000 runs out in February 2025.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Meanwhile, Grida said MALS is looking for other funders interested in backing the effort.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: CEO of Memphis Area Legal Services
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Meanwhile, Grida said MALS is looking for other funders interested in backing the effort.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Henderson believes the program will require a much longer pilot period before it’s able to produce the proof necessary to create a housing court. But, despite the rough start, she remains “very hopeful” for its future.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Henderson believes the program will require a much longer pilot period before it’s able to produce the proof necessary to create a housing court. But, despite the rough start, she remains “very hopeful” for its future.
